dialogueHeader.title: MARY MODERS
dialogueHeader.author: unknown
dialogueHeader.contemporaneity: Source text dates from same year as the first printing / original speech event

textBibliography.frontMatter: THE ARRAIGNMENT, TRYAL AND EXAMINATION OF MARY MODERS, OTHERWISE STEDMAN, NOW CARLETON, (STILED, THE GERMAN PRINCESS) AT THE SESSIONS-HOUSE IN THE OLD BAYLY, BEING BROUGHT PRISONER FROM THE GATE-HOUSE WESTMINSTER, FOR HAVING TWO HUSBANDS; VIZ. THO. STEDMAN OF CANTERBURY SHOOEMAKER AND JOHN CARLETON OF LONDON, GENT. WHO UPON A FULL HEARING WAS ACQUITTED BY THE JURY ON THURSDAY, JUNE 4. 1663. LONDON: PRINTED FOR N. BROOK, AT THE ANGEL IN CORNHIL, NEAR THE ROYAL EXCHANGE, 1663. PP. 2.21 - 3.23 SAMPLE 1 PP. 5.9 - 16.18 SAMPLE 2

dialogueText.comment: ROUND BRACKETS ON TITLE PAGE OF SOURCE TEXT REPRODUCED ABOVE.
SOURCE TEXT HAS NO PAGES NUMBERED 7 OR 8.

sample.dialogue: Mary Moders, alias Stedman, Thou standest indicted in London by the name of Mary Moders late of London Spinster, otherwise Mary Stedman, the wife of , &c.
sample.nonSpeech: And here the Indictment was read as above:
sample.dialogue: How sayst thou, Art thou guilty of the Felony, whereof thou standest indicted, or Not guilty?
Not guilty, my Lord.
How wilt thou be tryed?
By God and the Country.
God send thee a good deliverance.
sample.nonSpeech:
And afterwards she being set to the Bar in order to her Tryal, she prayed time till the morrow for her Tryal: which was granted; and all persons concerned were ordered to attend them at Nine of the Clock in the Fore-noon.
The Reader is desired to take notice of the following Passage. After she was Arraigned, and going back to the Gaol, her Husband the young Lord told her, He must now bid her Adieu for ever. To which she replyed:

dialogue.font: Nay, (My Lord) 'tis not amiss Before we part to have a Kiss.

sample.nonSpeech: And so saluted him, and said,
sample.dialogue: What a quarter and noise here's of a Cheat! You cheated me, and I you: You told me you were a Lord, and I told you I was a Princess; and I think I fitted you.
sample.nonSpeech: And so saluting each other, they parted.
sample.head: JUNE 4. 63.
sample.dialogue: Mary Moders , alias Stedman , hold up thy hand:

Those men that you shall hear called, and personally appear, are to pass between our Soveraign Lord the King and you for your life: if you will challenge them, or any of them, you must do it when they come to the Book to be sworn, before they are sworn.

dialogue.comment: LIST OF JURY MEMBERS' NAMES FOLLOWS.

sample.dialogue: My Lord, and Gentlemen of the Jury, I gave this woman in marriage to one Thomas Stedman , which is now alive in Dover , and I see him last week.
VVhere was she married?
In Canterbury .
VVhere there?
In St. Mildreds , by one Parson Man , who is now dead.
How long since were they married?
About nine years ago.
Did they live together afterwards?
Yes, about four years, and had two Children.
You gave her in marriage, but did the Minister give her to her husband then?
Yes, and they lived together.
Friend, did you give this very Woman?
Yes.
What company was there?
There was the married Couple, her sister, my self, the Parson and the Sexton.
Where is that Sexton?
I know not, my Lord.
You are sure they were married in the Church, and this is the woman?
Yes, I am sure of it.
How long ago?
About nine years ago.
Did you know this woman before the Marriage, and how long?
Yes, I knew her a long time. I was an Apprentice seven years near her Mothers house in Canterbury .
Then she's no Forreign Princess? Of what Parentage was she?
I did not know her own Father
sample.nonSpeech: (and in that he might be believed)
sample.dialogue: but her Father-in-law was a Musitian there.
You see her married: what words were used at her marriage, and in what manner?
They were married according to the order of the Land, a little before the Act came forth touching marriages by Justices of the Peace.
VVas it by the Form of Common-Prayer, any thing read of that Form?
I did not take notice of that, I was but a young man, and was desired to go along with them.

My Lord, I was last week in Dover in company with this James Knot and Thomas Stedman , and he the said Stedman did own that he did marry one Mary Moders , a daughter of one in Canterbury , and that Knot gave her, and that he had two Children by her, and declared his willingness to come up to give evidence against her, but wanted money for his journey: And I have understood that a person here in Court was of a Jury at Canterbury , at a Tryal between Day and Mary Stedman at the Bar for having two Husbands.
Was she cleared?
I cannot tell.

My Lord, I was at Dover the last week on Wednesday; I saw the husband of this woman, and the man acknowledged himself to be so; and did say that James Knot was the man that gave her in marriage to him.
VVhere is this man her husband? Hearsays must condemn no man: what do you know of your own knowledge?
I know the man is alive.
Do you know he was married to her?
Not I, my Lord. SOURCE TEXT HAS NO PAGES NUMBERED 7 OR 8.

My Lord, This Woman was bound for Barbadoes , to go along with my Husband, and she desired to lodge at our house for some time, and did so; and when the ship was ready to go, she went into Kent to receive her means, and said she would meet the ship in the Downe ; and missing the ship, took boat and went to the ship. After several days remaining there, there came her Husband with an Order and fetched her ashore, and carried her to Dover Castle.
What was his name that had an Order to bring her on shore again?
His name was Thomas Stedman .
Have you any more to prove the first marriage?
No, none but Knot ; there was none but the three, the Minister dead, the Sexton not to be found; and this Knot who hath given Evidence.
What became of the two Children, Knot ?
They both died.
Stedman said in my hearing, that he had lived four years together, had two Children by her, and both dead; five years ago last Easter since she left him.
Mr. Charlton , What have you heard this Woman say?
My Lord, she will confess nothing that pleases him.
Mr. Charlton , Did you look in the Church Register for the first marriage.

I did look in the Book, and he that is now Clerk, was then Sexton (just now not to be found,) he told me, that Marriages being then very numerous preceeding the Act before-mentioned, the then Clerk had neglected the Registry of this Marriage. If she intended this Trade, she likewise knew how to make the Clerk mistake Registring the Marriage.
sample.nonSpeech: Young Charlton's Brother sworn, who said,
sample.dialogue:
My Lord and Gentlemen of the Jury, I was present at the Marriage of my Brother with this Gentlewoman, which was on or about 21 April, 1663. They were married at Great SOURCE TEXT: Gre FOLLOWED BY TWO SPACES
St. Bartholomews , by one Mr. Smith a Minister here in Court by Licence.
My Lord, all that I can say, is this, That Mr. Charlton the younger told me of such a business, and desired me to marry them; they came to Church, and I did marry them by the Book of Common Prayer.
Mr. Smith , are you sure that is the Woman?
Yes, my Lord, it is; I believe she will not deny it.
Yes, my Lord, I confess I am the Woman.
Have you any more witnesses.
We can get no more but Knot to prove the first Marriage, the last is clear.

Where is Knot ? Remember your self well what you said before. You say, you know that Woman at the Bar; that you had known her a great while; that she was born near you in Canterbury ; that you were present at her marriage; that Parson Man married them; that none were present but your self, the married couple, Parson, Sexton, and her sister.
Some others came into the Church, but none that I knew; I am sure none went with her, but those I named.
Who gave her in marriage?
I did.
How came you to do it?
I was Stedmans shopmate, and he desired me to go along with him.
Were her Parents then living, or no?
Her Mother was.
How old are you?
Two or Three and thirty years.
How long ago was this marriage?
About 9 years since.
Then he was Twenty three, and might do it: What is your Trade of life?
I am a Cordweyner, otherwise a Shoomaker Stedman was so too; we wrought both together.
We desire to know whether she had a Father and Mother then living?
She had a Father-in-law.
Did you know her Mother?
Yes.
How long before that Marriage did her own Father die?
I did not know him;
What age was she when married?

I suppose about Nineteen or twenty. PRISONER'S LONG SPEECH OMITTED. SHE CLAIMS THAT HER HUSBAND AND HIS FATHER HAVE ACCUSED HER OF BIGAMY IN ORDER TO GAIN POSSESSION OF HER FORTUNE, WHICH SHE REFUSED TO MAKE OVER TO HER HUSBAND. SHE CLAIMS NOT TO BE THE SAME WOMAN AS THAT MARRIED IN CANTERBURY, AND THAT SEVERAL OF THIS WOMAN'S FRIENDS WHO CAME TO THE JAIL DECLARED THEY DID NOT KNOW HER.

Knot , You said she lived near you at Canterbury ; What woman or man there have you to prove she lived there? have you none in that whole City, neither for love of Justice nor Right, will come to say she lived there?
I believe I could fetch one.
Well said, are they to fetch still?
My Lord, I desire some Witnesses may be heard in my behalf.

My Lord, my Husband being a Prisoner in the Gatehouse , I came there to see my Husband, and did work there a dayes; and where came in an old man, his name was Billing , he said he had a wife there; sayes Mr. Baley go in and find her out; and he said I was his Wife, turned my hood, and put on his spectacles, looks upon me, and said I was the same woman his wife, and afterwards said I was not, and so to others: I can say no more.

My Lord, there came a man and a woman one night, and knockt at my door; I came down, they asked to speak with
one Jane Finch ; I am the person, said I, We understand, said they, you know Mrs. Charleton now in prison; Not I, said I, I only went to see her there; said they, be not scrupulous, if you will go and justifie any thing against her, we will give you 5 l.
Who are those two?
I do not know them, My Lord.

My Lord, there has been at least 500 people have viewed her; several from Canterbury , 40 at least that said they lived there; and when they went up to her, she hid not her face at all, but not one of them knew her.
What Countrey woman are you?
I was born in Cullen in Germany .
Mr. Charlton , How came you to understand she was married formerly?
I received a Letter from the Recorder of Canterbury to that purpose.
They that can offer 5 l. to swear against me, can also frame a Letter against me: They say I was 19 years of age about 9 years ago, and am now but 21.
Mr. Charlton , you heard what Knot said; he said she lived near him 4. years a wife, why did not you get some body else from thence to testifie this?
Here was one Davis that was at her Fathers house, and spoke with him --
Where is he?
I know not; he was here.
You were telling the Court of a former Indictment against her, what was that for?

She was indicted for having two husbands, Stedman of Canterbury her first Husband, and Day of Dover Chirurgion, her second Husband. The Indictment was Traversed the year before His Majesty came to England , she was found not guilty.
Who was at that tryal?

One here in Court was of the Jury: but that party said there was such a tryal, but knows not that this is the Woman.
JUDGE'S SUMMING UP SPEECH OMITTED.
sample.nonSpeech: The Jury went forth, and after some short Consultation, returned to their places. Their names were called, and all answered.
sample.dialogue: Are you all agreed of your Verdict?
Yes.
Who shall say for you?
The Foreman.
Mary Moders alias Stedman hold up thy hand, look upon her Gentlemen, what say you, Is she guilty of the Felony whereof she stands indicted, or not guilty?
Not guilty.
sample.nonSpeech: And thereupon a great number of people being in and about the Court, hissed and clapped their hands.
sample.dialogue: Did she flie for it?
Not that we know.
